content.question:
A researcher collected data on the latitude, in degrees north of the equator, and the average low temperature, in degrees Fahrenheit, for a random sample of cities in Europe. The data were used to create the following equation for the least-squares regression line. <math alttext="predicted average low temperature equals, 65.5 minus 0.70, open parenthesis, latitude, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>predicted average low temperature</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>65.5</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>0.70</mn><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>latitude</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
Which of the following is the best interpretation of the slope of the line?

choices.label: For each one degree north of the equator increase, the predicted average low temperature increases on average by <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree Fahrenheit.

For each one degree north of the equator increase, the predicted average low temperature decreases on average by <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree Fahrenheit.

For each <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree north of the equator increase, the predicted average low temperature decreases on average by <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree Fahrenheit.

For each one degree Fahrenheit increase in average low temperature, the predicted latitude increases on average by <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree north of the equator.

For each one degree Fahrenheit increase in average low temperature, the predicted latitude decreases on average by <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree north of the equator.

content.answer: For each one degree north of the equator increase, the predicted average low temperature decreases on average by <math alttext="0.70" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degree Fahrenheit.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
